data.title: JetBlue CEO Talks Airlines, Aspirations
data.meta_description: Tells SMG students: âDonât take the first job that comes alongâ
data.text:
David Barger, JetBlue president and CEO, liberally mixed humor and candor throughout an hour-long discussion last week at the School of Management about JetBlueâs success in an airline industry buffeted by bankruptcies, mergers, and acquisitions.

Barger was greeted by a standing-room-only crowd for the SMG Deanâs Speaker Series, where he and Kenneth Freeman, the schoolâs Allen Questrom Professor and Dean, discussed Bargerâs career path, his leadership style, and the future of airlines. Students were invited to ask questions during the second half of the session, and two lucky participants earned a pair of free tickets.

In a nod to the packed room, Freeman remarked, âWe have full capacity utilization, which is great in the airline industry.â

Barger, who helped found JetBlue 14 years ago, was the latest guest in the speaker series, which has brought to campus industry stars like Adam Bryant, New York Times senior editor for features, Ed Weiss, general counsel of the Boston Red Sox and Fenway Sports Group, and Gustavo Valle, CEO of Dannon.

Barger, whose father was a pilot with United Airlines, grew up in the airline industry. But with less than 20/20 vision, flying was not an option. Instead, he took a job in Detroit as a $5.50-an-hour customer service agent with New York Air. âI think it was one of the best things that happened to me,â he said. âIt allowed me to really end up working on the ground and making my way up through the leadership ranks.â

Barger earned his first general manager position in New Orleans and stayed with New York Air from 1982 through 1988. He then hopped to Continental Airlines, where he served in various management positions, including regional director in Guam and then vice president of the companyâs Newark hub. âThereâs just so much opportunity if you donât tie yourself to one geographic location, especially in this business,â he said.

In 1998, Barger teamed with David Neeleman to found JetBlue, a scrappy start-up in a world of airline giants. âDonât be afraid to get involved in something thatâs entrepreneurial,â he advised students. âYou can always come back in terms of a traditional airline. If you have the opportunity to create something new as opposed to just implementing somebody elseâs vision, thatâs an awful lot of fun.â

The company is now the fifth largest airline in the country, with 15,000 crew members and service to 80 destinations (including Worcester, Mass., as of November 7, the company announced last week) in 14 countries, with 30 percent of its travel to the Caribbean and Latin America.

But flying JetBlue hasnât been all blue skies. Barger was the airlineâs chief operating officer when a winter storm struck in February 2007, stranding hundreds of passengers on the tarmac for up to 11 hours in some places. The event threw the company into turmoil, lifted Barger to the rank of CEO, and taught everyone in the industry some valuable lessons. One, he said, was simple: âMother Nature, sheâs going to win. So let her win.â Another was for the company to cool its jets, so to speak, and grow at a more measured pace.

The open secret to JetBlueâs success isnât just that the company has strong financials and the best seats and airfares, Barger said. âAt the end of the day, that can all be replicated,â he said. âIt does come down to the human equation. Itâs our frontline crew members who are making the difference.â

JetBlue employees are not unionized, and Barger is proud of that. âI just donât think you have to pay somebody to speak for you in terms of how weâre building our culture,â he said. âWe want the loyalty to the company as opposed to the third party.â

Barger said loyalty grows when employees respect, and connect with, their leader. For that reason, he takes care to attend new hire orientations, travel frequently, keep active on Twitter, and support socially responsible actions, like the companyâs effort to plant one million trees along New Yorkâs Queens-Brooklyn border.

Good managers should ask themselves one question when they look in the mirror, Barger said: Would you like to report to yourself? If the answer is yes, then theyâre on the right path. And when a challenge arises, he added, âtackle it. Donât try to put it underground.â

When Freeman opened the discussion to students, some wanted to know about the industryâs future (expect better in-flight entertainment, faster check-in, and satellite-based cockpit navigation), his day-to-day life (âDo you want people to leave the room now?â), and his most beneficial college experience (his political science courses at the University of Michigan).

But on the tip of everyoneâs tongue was: what advice does Barger have for job seekers?

âDonât take the first thing that comes along,â he said. âLook for places that stretch you, if you want to be stretched. Make sure that they stretch you.â
